text: southern Spain 1995 high in the Sierra
Nevada mountains astronomer Benjamin
Zuckerman explores an unusual star about
190 light-years from Earth in the
distant Cetus constellation we weren't
really sure what we might find so
although it definitely was a well moment
to see 49 set at the time we did not
realize quite how unusual it was going
to turn out to be the star is surrounded
by two enormous rings one of the Rings
has a radius I think of about a billion
miles the other one is two or three
times that size farther out and so these
are our rings that are occurring in
places where you would expect planets to
form for an astronomer the obvious
conclusion is that he's looking at rings
of dust and gas which often encircle
young stars
but after years of observation sacrament
discovers that 49 Ceti is not young at
all the stars about 40 or 50 million
years old which makes it the oldest star
we know of with these dusty debris disk
once a star gets older about 5 million
years most of the gas that's orbiting in
these distant dissipates and dust
particles either get blown away from
stars or they spiral into stars and
that's one of the great mysteries
there's some process that's replenishing
the gas into this disk system and we
don't see that process going on in our
planetary system it's hard to kind of
get in your head the mystery of what
holds together the rings around 49 Ceti
raises some intriguing questions
questions conventional science can
struggle to answer when we can't explain
what we see with what we know we have to
start explaining with what we don't
perhaps the most extraordinary idea for
what the Rings could be comes from the
realm of science fiction the concept of
a giant ring shaped world surrounding a
star was first proposed by novelist
Larry Niven Larry Nivens original ring
world concept would take the material of
some useless planets and use them to
pound out a ribbon the surrounds a star
and this ribbon is kept inflated by
centrifugal force resulting in millions
of times more useful surface area
for a civilization being able to support
trillions of people so it's a
fascinating concept the idea of another
civilization building a ring world
around 49 Ceti is humbling for Humanity
especially as we struggle to reach our
nearest planet any civilization that
would be capable of making a ring world
around its star would be lightyears
ahead of us probably tens of millions of
years ahead of us in technological
superiority
